importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The new citizenship test requirements apply to green card holders who file for citizenship after October 20, 2025.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The changes to the naturalization process, including the new civics test and moral character requirements, are being implemented starting in 2025 as part of the Trump administration's policy shift.

keyTakeAways: The Trump administration is making it harder for immigrants to become U.S. citizens by increasing the difficulty of the oral civics test.
Applicants now must answer 12 out of 20 questions correctly, doubling the current requirement of 6 out of 10.
The pool of possible questions is expanding from 100 to 128, with more difficult and complex questions replacing easier ones such as geography facts.
Questions about U.S. holidays, basic geography, and short-answer facts (e.g., 'What ocean is on the West Coast?') are being removed or reduced.
New questions include political history topics such as 'Why did the U.S. enter the Persian Gulf War?' and 'Why did the U.S. enter the Vietnam War?'
Applicants must now demonstrate 'good moral character' by submitting evidence of positive contributions to American society.
Immigration officers will conduct more rigorous background checks, possibly interviewing coworkers, family members, or neighbors.
Critics, including legal experts and advocacy groups, argue that the changes disproportionately impact individuals with low literacy or limited access to preparation resources.
University of Virginia professor Amanda Frost questions the evidence that the current naturalization process fails to screen for shared values or democratic participation.
She notes that immigrants and their descendants have historically founded major U.S. companies and contributed to economic and cultural growth.
The changes are framed by USCIS as restoring 'integrity' and ensuring 'full assimilation' and alignment with American values.

namedEntities.name: Trump administration
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A governing body under the leadership of former President Donald Trump, responsible for implementing policy changes related to immigration and citizenship.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Trump administration is directly responsible for introducing and enforcing changes to the U.S. naturalization test, including increasing the difficulty of the civics exam and introducing new moral character requirements.

namedEntities.name: U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A federal agency responsible for processing naturalization applications and immigration-related services.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: USCIS is the official body that administers and enforces the new citizenship test requirements, including the increased question count, expanded question pool, and moral character standards.

namedEntities.name: Adrian Florido
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A reporter for NPR who covered the article on changes to the naturalization test.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Adrian Florido is the author and primary source of the news article, providing factual reporting and contextual analysis of the policy changes.

namedEntities.name: Mary Louise Kelly
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A host of NPR’s 'All Things Considered' program.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Mary Louise Kelly is the host who aired the segment discussing the changes to the citizenship test, thus bringing the topic to a broader public audience.

namedEntities.name: Joseph Edlow
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Director of USCIS at the time of the article.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Joseph Edlow stated that the current test is 'too easy' and that more in-depth knowledge of U.S. values is needed to assess true integration into American society.

namedEntities.name: Amanda Frost
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Professor of immigration law at the University of Virginia and author of 'You Are Not American'.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Amanda Frost provides critical analysis, challenging the administration's claim that the current test is too lenient and questioning whether the new standards are justified or evidence-based.

namedEntities.name: Central American Resource Center (CARC)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An advocacy organization offering citizenship preparation courses in Los Angeles.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Central American Resource Center represents advocates who are concerned that the new test poses significant barriers—especially for low-literacy and under-resourced applicants.

namedEntities.name: Persian Gulf War
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A military conflict in which the United States participated, used as a test question in the revised citizenship exam.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The war is included as a new, more complex question about U.S. foreign policy and historical involvement, signaling a shift toward politically oriented civics testing.

namedEntities.name: Vietnam War
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major U.S. military conflict referenced in the new test as a question about U.S. foreign policy.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The inclusion of the Vietnam War reflects the administration’s emphasis on testing applicants’ understanding of U.S. political decisions and foreign policy history.

namedEntities.name: Green card holders
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Non-citizens who have been legally granted permission to live and work in the U.S. for a specified period.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Green card holders are directly affected by the new naturalization rules, which require them to meet stricter standards for citizenship.

namedEntities.name: Fortune 500 companies
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A list of the largest U.S. corporations, used by critics to support the argument that immigrants have contributed to economic growth.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The fact that nearly half of Fortune 500 companies were founded by immigrants or their children is cited as evidence that naturalized immigrants are valuable contributors to the economy.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Trump administration is implementing stricter requirements for U.S. citizenship, including a more difficult civics test that requires applicants to answer 12 out of 20 questions correctly—doubling the current standard—while expanding the question pool from 100 to 128 and replacing basic geography and holiday questions with more complex political history questions. Applicants must now demonstrate 'good moral character' through evidence of positive contributions to society, with immigration officers conducting deeper background checks, including interviews with coworkers or neighbors. USCIS cites a need to ensure full assimilation and alignment with American values, but critics—including legal experts and advocacy groups—argue that the changes are unjustified, disproportionately affect low-literacy and under-resourced populations, and lack evidence that current naturalization standards fail to uphold democratic values. The changes are part of a broader policy effort to limit immigration and strengthen integration requirements.
title: The test for U.S. citizenship is about to get harder
